NOTE: Christopher Eccleston informed Edmonton fans via a video on Instagram on Thursday afternoon that he is unable to attend Edmonton Expo this weekend. The former Doctor Who actor cited family circumstances involving his children as the reason he is unable to travel. Edmonton Expo also announced Thursday on Twitter that Joonas Suatomo, the actor playing Chewbacca in the latest Star Wars movies, has cancelled his appearance due to illness. Edmonton Expo said on Twitter that it will be offering refunds on admission tickets until 2 p.m. Friday. People are asked to email edmontontickets@fanexpohq.com with their transaction ID to get a refund.

(Update: Unfortunately Eccleston was forced to cancel his appearance at Edmonton Expo due to personal reasons.)

His single-year performance as the war-traumatized, last of the Time Lords, next-regeneration Doctor in 2005 was a fantastic effort, helping re-energize the dormant series which to this day thrives on BBC â€” Jodie Whittaker now playing the lead four incarnations on.

But bring up Eccleston to almost anyone into fringe pop culture and theyâ€™ll fetishize his roles in Shallow Grave, Cracker, 28 Days Later, or the harrowing and beautiful The Leftovers, where he plays a priest in a world where neither faith nor science explain why 2 per cent of the worldâ€™s population simply disappears one Oct. 14 without so much as a Thanos-snap, though there is a lot of ominous smoke.

Eccleston is sitting in his car outside the chemist in Crouch End, London, for one of my favourite conversations in ages, which in its edited form, goes like this:

Q: I just watched 28 hours of The Leftovers in three days, so my eyes feel like peeled grapes. You were wonderful in that, how do you feel about the show?

A: Thatâ€™s a very strange thing to do to your brain.

Itâ€™s in my top five favourites as a finished piece of work and as an experience. We had an interesting experience because I think we all felt we hadnâ€™t done our best with the first series, tonally, narratively.

But two episodes sort of popped: The episode with myself and the episode with Carrie Coon, those kind of landed just purely because of the form, I think, concentrating on one character. In the second series we got extraordinary reviews, the third even better. And then Damon Lindelof, who of course became famous for pissing a lot of people off with his finales (laughs), heâ€™s probably on record as the man with the worst reviews and the best reviews for a finale, which is Lost and then The Leftovers.

I love the show. I adored making it; the cast and crew. And that character is one of the best Iâ€™ve ever been given.

Q: Your episodes in particular are full of hope and disappointment and then hope again. Is your life a little like that? Is everybodyâ€™s?

The pilot script came in and I was asked to audition for the lead and I felt that was a long shot because Iâ€™m not your traditional handsome-looking leading man. But I somehow got an e-mail through to Damon saying â€˜I really want to be in this and I really want to play Matt Jamisonâ€™ and the response was, â€˜Matt Jamison isnâ€™t in the series!â€™ So he was over in London publicizing Star Trek and we met and talked about the book, and he claims I said a person not taken in the Rapture would get more religious. Thatâ€™s apparently what I said, it sounds far too intellectual for me. But he went away and made him a preacher obsessed, and over-identifying with the biblical Job. And that was it. I was in. I was in, because of that conversation. I kind of talked my way in.

Q: Iâ€™m still trying to unpack it philosophically, itâ€™s still fresh. One thing I like about it is itâ€™s not necessarily an allegory for anything political, which is a little rare these days. I mean, thereâ€™s 9-11 in there, but itâ€™s a lot wider in scope than that.

A: I can tell you what (author) Tom Perrotta said to me. I asked him â€˜what made you write this novelâ€™ and he said, â€˜I didnâ€™t know that until after Iâ€™d written it.â€™ He was playing tennis in New York with his son on a beautiful summerâ€™s day thinking it was just great, and later there was a phone call out of the blue and he was told his parents had been involved in a road accident and his father had died. Three years later he found himself writing a novel about sudden departure. He said, â€˜I think, Chris, that was the triggerâ€™ â€” how we, the leftovers, deal with sudden death.

Q: I once went to Salford chasing the spot where the Smiths took the photo in front of the Salford Lads Club â€” is that a familiar spot to you?

A: Oh yeah, I was born in Salford and the Smiths were my band, the only white guitar band Iâ€™ve ever loved. But of course Morrissey has really shat on that legacy with some of his bigotry.

Iâ€™ve always maintained you could listen to the Smiths albums without the lyrics and the voice. If you read the book Songs That Changed Your Life, etc., Johnny Marr was musically and sonically and from a business sense was a bigger part of the Smiths. Itâ€™s like, can we listen to Michael Jackson any more? I certainly canâ€™t. I find it very difficult to listen to Morrissey now, and I adored Morrissey. I think we can celebrate what he did with the Smiths: literate, politically informed, melodic, outsider champion â€” it was very early on he was championing inclusiveness for a beautiful set of albums, very important to me. Getting out of Salford and Manchester, moving to London, thinking that I had something to say. It was hugely important to my generation, working class people who wanted to go into the arts.

Q: Can you tell me about playing Macbeth at the Royal Shakespeare Company â€” that role was important to you early on, correct?

A: I was in a production of Macbeth when I was 17 playing the bloody Sergeant and Macduff. It was on that night a key drama teacher came up to me and said, â€˜You know, Chris, I never really felt you could do this. But tonight I felt you might have a future.â€™ The combination of criticism and encouragement was very potent and from that night on I pursued it. At 17, my ambition became to play Macbeth at the RFC. And I did it last year.

Q: This is a weird one, but could you feel yourself reaching back through time?

A: Yes, yes I could! I donâ€™t know if you remember a film called East Is East. The guy who wrote that, Ayub Khan Din, he grew up to write that film, and bizarrely my mother and father used to go into his chip shop when they were courting. Ayub played Macbeth, I got to watch it every night, and I became obsessed with it. I thought my father, who worked in a factory, could be that man. I couldnâ€™t imagine him being Hamlet or Henry V, but I could imagine my father being a very ambitious military man, working class and he could physically look after himself. Someone said, it might have been Harold Bloom, Shakespeare gave Hamlet all of his intellectual genius; he gave Macbeth the whole of his poetic imagination. And itâ€™s Macbethâ€™s imagination that destroys him. Iâ€™ve been told somebody whoâ€™s a soldier could not have a poetic imagination, but I knew that to be a lie. I felt I could play him. And I found out I couldnâ€™t, I was very disappointed in my performance. But Iâ€™m very, very glad I had a go at it.

A: Broadly definitely I much prefer theatre acting, because the surge of adrenalin is much higher and the reaction is immediate. Iâ€™ve worked with some great writers, like Jimmy McGovern (Accused), Peter Flannery (Our Friends in the North) and Russell T Davies (Doctor Who).

But the greatest of them all is William Shakespeare, to be able to internalize and explore that language â€” I did 119 performances of Macbeth.

But what I enjoy about film and television, and this may sound a bit strange, is when the cameraâ€™s not on you, and youâ€™re working with a very good actor, and theyâ€™re reaching for something, you can support them. You can be supportive and help them get the best out of them. And thereâ€™s something very special that passes between actors, and I really enjoy the communion.

Someone described television as poetic ideas realized industrially. And thatâ€™s what you have to do, ignore the hardware and reach out to the actor in front of you. I was mad on sport, and I didnâ€™t really enjoy scoring goals, I enjoyed creating the pass.

Q: You seem drawn to characters with a fair pinch of darkness â€” or is that just whatâ€™s happened to you since Shallow Grave?

A: I think that comes from my father, from my background, which was reasonably tough. My father was a tough man. Iâ€™m publishing a book called I Love the Bones of You, a memoir of my relationship with my father, particularly through his years of dementia. Iâ€™m a dinosaur, born in â€™64, brought up in a very patriarchy, masculine, chauvinistic environment. I felt my father was all of those things. But within him was this great vulnerability and sensitivity he was afraid to show. He seemed a slightly dangerous man, and thatâ€™s informed how I played David Stevens in Shallow Grave.
